Course Description: The objective of this course is to provide introduction to network biology, an emerging interdisciplinary area which aims at graph theoretical modeling of biological complex systems and its applications. The student will be provided with conceptual understanding of complex networks and their application for modeling various biological systems. Through a combination of lectures, exercises, and assignments, the student is expected to achieve understanding of network biology.

Prerequisites.Mandatory: Knowledge of data structures, algorithms and programming

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to explain basic concepts of complex networks.
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to explain network models of biological systems (PPIN, GRN, RIG, Metabolic, Ecological and Brain Networks).
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to interpret results from network analysis of biological systems.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Students are able to code and implement simple network models of biological systems.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Introduction to complex networks: History, Computational representation of networks, Applications in biology
Introduction to systems biology and network models of biological systems
Network metrics: Definitions, interpretations and application to biological networks
Small-world and scale-free networks: Biological implications
Modeling complex diseases as molecular networks
Network metrics: Definitions, interpretations and application to biological networks
Modularity, Hierarchy, Motifs and biological implications
Residue Interaction Graph models of protein structures

Textbook: The Structure of Complex Networks: Theory and Applications by Ernesto Estrada (Oxford University Press)
Networks: An Introduction by M. E. J. Newman (Oxford University Press)
